In addition, the group visited the websites related to "state and county offices responsible for administering the 2016 U.S. elections" in several states, including Georgia, Iowa, and Florida, to "identify vulnerabilities."

Rosenstein said that his team had determined that these 12 Russians were also behind the websites "DCLeaks" and "Guccifer 2.0," which they used to release information that they had stolen through hacking and spearphishing.

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein announced Friday that the grand jury for the District of Columbia indicted 12 Russians on charges related to attempts to influence the 2016 presidential election.

The Russians also sent more than 100 spearphishing emails to "organizations and personnel involved in administering elections in numerous Florida counties" in and around election day in November 2016.
According to Rosenstein, the GRU officers “hacked the website of a state election board, and stole information of about 500,000 voters.” The indictment does not specify which state had been hacked.
When we confront foreign interference in American elections, it is important for us to avoid thinking politically as Republicans or Democrats and instead to think patriotically as Americans.
Among the victims targeted in these attacks were the Democratic National Committee, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, and the Hillary Clinton Campaign.
Eleven of the 12 Russians are charged with money laundering, aggravated identity theft, and conspiracy to commit computer crimes.
In his announcement, Rosenstein made it a point not to specifically name Hillary Clinton or the Democratic National Committee.

Rosenstein also warned that:

People who speculate about federal investigations often do not know all the relevant facts.
Spearphishing involves sending someone an email that looks like it came from a sender that they trust.
Using these methods, the Russians released "tens of thousands of stolen emails and documents."

He addressed why he made this decision:

In my remarks, I have not identified the victims.
The GRU is an intelligence agency and part of the Russian military.
The recipient is then often asked to enter personal information.
Our response must not depend on who was victimized.
These indictments targeted 12 GRU officers.
All 12 were indicted for hacking.
Who were the Russians indicted?
What were the charges?
What else?
